File.Title: Origin of Spinal Projections to the Anterior and Posterior Lobes of the Rat Cerebellum
File.Authors: SABINA BERRETTA, VINCENZO PERCIAVALLE, AND RICHARD E. POPPELE

Abstract.S: The present study was carried out to analyze the topography of spinal projections to the anterior and posterior lobes of the cerebellum and to investigate whether projections to the two lobes come from different spinocerebellar neurons or from branching axons of the same cells.

We used orthograde transport of horseradish peroxidase conjugated with wheat germ agglutinin (WGA-HRP) to identify the cerebellar areas where spinocerebellar axons terminate and retrograde double-labeling techniques to estimate the incidence of spinocerebellar neurons projecting to both anterior and posterior lobes via axon collaterals.

Orthograde labeling confirmed that the rat, like other mammalian species, has spinocerebellar projections to two different regions of cerebellar cortex, i.e., lobules I-V of the anterior lobe and lobule VIII of the posterior lobe, with the highest incidence in lobules 11,111, and VIII.
We did not observe a clear difference in the distribution of afferents coming from different spinal segments to either of the two lobes.

The double-labeled cells were located primarily in the lower thoracic and upper lumbar segments, almost exclusively in Clarke's column and in the dorso-lateral part of lamina 7 (in the region of the spinal border cells).
It is likely that most or all of the spinocerebellar neurons in these structures project to both anterior and posterior lobes.

Therefore, the two lobes of the cerebellum are likely to receive common information from these cells, but different information from the separate populations of spinocerebellar neurons that project only to one lobe or the other.

Introduction.S: It has been well demonstrated that information carried by spinocerebellar systems reaches two different regions of paleocerebellar cortex in several mammalian species, namely, lobules I-V of the anterior lobe and lobule VIII of the posterior lobe (Snyder et al., '78; Matsushita and Ikeda, '80, '81; Klinkachorn and Culberson, '88).
Electrophysiological experiments have shown that the response patterns of Purkinje cells to passive hind-foot rotations are different in these two cerebellar areas (Perciavalle et al., '89).
However, it is not yet known whether the spinocerebellar projections to the two cerebellar lobes arise from different neurons or from neurons which send axon branches to both lobes.

A recent study of the projections to anterior and posterior lobes in the cat examined spinocerebellar neurons in the lower lumbar and sacral segments, and found very few cells projecting to both cerebellar areas (Xu and Grant, '88).

The present investigation examines this possibility further for spinocerebellar projections from the entire spinal cord in the rat by using orthograde transport of horseradish peroxidase conjugated with wheat germ agglutinin (WGAHRP) to identify the cerebellar areas reached by spinocerebellar fibers and the retrograde double-labeling techniques to identify and quantify the incidence of spinocerebellar neurons projecting to both areas via axon collaterals.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Experiments were carried out on 21 male Wistar rats (200 to 280 g) deeply anesthetized with urethane (Sigma; 1.2 g/kgi.p.).
Methods for orthograde labeling
Twelve rats were given hydraulic injections of a 4% solution of WGA-HRP dissolved in 0.9% saline through glass micropipettes with 40-60 pm tips connected to a 1 pl Hamilton syringe.
The assembly was inserted into the spinal cord under microscopic guidance.

Injections of 40-50 nl were made unilaterally into several cord levels: cervical (3 cases; Cl-C2, C2-C4, and C5-C6), cervico-thoracic (1 case; C8-T2), thoracic (2 cases; Tl-T2 and T7-T8), thoracolumbar (2 cases; I ll-L1 and T12-L3), lumbar (2 cases; L2-L5 and L3-L5 I , lumbo-sacral(1 case; L5-S2) and sacral (1 case; Sl-S3).
Each area was exposed by laminectomy of the two adjacent vertebrae and particular care was taken to control a possible spread of enzyme in the subarachnoid space.
All animals in which spread was detected were excluded from the analysis.

After a 3-4 day survival period, the rats were reanesthetized with urethane and perfused sequentially with 500 ml of 0.9% saline at 42 C, 500 ml of 1.25% gluteraldehyde-1% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) at room temperature, and 500 ml of an ice-cold 10% sucrose solution in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brains and injected spinal cord sections were removed and placed in the same 10% sucrose and phosphate buffer at 4°C until sectioned.

Frozen sections (20 pm) were cut, collected in 0.1 M pH 7.4 phosphate buffer, processed with tetramethylbenzidine (Sigma) and incubated with hydrogen peroxide, according to the method of Mesulam ( 78).
Sections through the injection site were treated with benzidine dihydrochloride (Sigma) according to the protocol of Mesulam ( 76) in order to determine the core uptake area.
This method reduces the axonal labeling characteristic of the tetramethylbenzidine method and thus does not blur the limits of the injection sites.
The sections were transferred into a sodium acetate buffer solution at 4°C and mounted on glass slides coated with chrome alurn.

To facilitate the identification of cytoarchitectonic details, half of the sections processed for HRP were counterstained with 1% neutral red (pH 4.81, while the other half were left uncounterstained to reduce the loss of reaction product.
Finally, all sections, counterstained or not, were dehydrated with ethanol, cleared with xylene, and covered using Entellan (Merck) and glass coverslips.
The slides were examined with both brightand darkfield illumination.
Crossed polarizers were placed in the light path to produce an intensified image of reaction products.

The effective uptake areas were considered as the zones surrounding the HRP injection sites where deposition of reaction-product was very dense and where individual labeled axons and perikarya could not be detected (Horton et al., 79).
The pattern of orthogradely transported label, judged by conventional criteria (Mesulam, 821, was plotted on camera lucida drawings of the sections.

In cases of uncertainty, i.e., fine dust-like label which might represent either terminal labeling or fibers cut in cross-section, the areas were examined with high magnification (1,188~) to identify possible terminal ramifications.
Photographs were taken of salient features.
Method for double-labeling
We used two different protocols for double-labeling.

In the first, five animals were given hydraulic injections of two fluorescent tracers: the cytoplasmic tracer Fast Blue (FB; 2 ~ 1 3% , w/v, Sigma) and the nuclear tracer Diamidin0 Yellow dihydrochloride (DY; 2 ~ 1 2% , w/v, Sigma; Kuypers et al., 80).
In three rats, FB was injected unilaterally in the anterior lobe and DY ipsilaterally in the posterior lobe.
In two other rats the DY was injected anterior and the FB posterior.

In the second protocol, four rats were injected with a fluorescent tracer, Fluoro Gold (FG; Schmued and Fallon, 86) and a non-fluorescent and non-diffusible retrogradely transported marker, colloidal gold (Au) conjugated with wheat germ agglutin (WGA)-enzymatically inactive horseradish peroxidase (apoHRP) complex (WGAapoHRP-Au; Basbaum and Menetrey, 87).

Gold particles approximately 10-12 km in diameter were prepared according to Muhlpfordi s ( 82) protocol by treating 100 ml of cholroauric acid (Sigma; 0.01% w/v in distilled water) with reducing agents (2 ml sodium citrate and 0.1 ml tannic acid, each 1% wiv in distilled water).
Liophilized WGAapoHRP (Sigma) was coupled to the colloidal gold according to the procedure of Basbaum and Menetrey ( 87).
Briefly, the gold solution was added to diluted (WGAapoHRP (1 mg protein per ml distilled water) and stirred.
The supernatant was aspirated and discarded and a soft 10-15 ~1 pellet containing WGAapoHRP-Au complex was ready for injection.
The FG (Fluorochrome) was dissolved in distilled water (4% v/v).
In two rats, FG was injected unilaterally in the anterior lobe and WGAapoHRP-Au in the posterior.
In the other two animals the injection sites were reversed.
The injections were made by pressure through glass micropipettes cemented to a 5 ~1 Hamilton syringe inserted according to the stereotaxic coordinates of Paxinos and Watson s atlas ( 86).
After a 5-7 day survival period the rats were reanesthetized with urethane and perfused according to the protocol described above for the HRP studies.
The brains and spinal cords were removed and placed overnight in the same ice-cold 10% sucrose in phosphate buffer solution and then for 3-4 days in a 30% sucrose in phosphate buffer solution at 4°C.
Sagittal (brain) and transverse (spinal cord) frozen sections (30 pm) were cut and mounted on glass slides coated with chrome alum.
Half the slides were counterstained with 1% neutral red and all were dehydrated, cleared and covered as described above.
The sections were analyzed using an Axioplan microscope (Zeiss) with brightand darkfield illumination as well as fluorescent emission.
Labeled cells in the spinal cord were drawn on camera lucida outlines and the number in each spinal area was counted.
The boundaries of the injection sites in the cerebellum were traced using a 2 . 5 ~ objective.
The fluorescent injection areas had two concentric fluorescent zones around the needle track.
The uptake of tracers by terminals and damaged fibers appears to occur only in the inner zone (cf.
Huisman et al., 82, 83).
Injected areas were quantitatively evaluated by adapting the method of Wolf and Gollob ( 80).

Results.S: RESULTS
Orthograde labeling experiments

TTE.S: Hydraulic injections of WGA-HRP solution in the spinal cords of 12 rats were distributed from the upper cervical to lower sacral levels.

Orthogradely labeled axons from each level of the spinal cord entered the restiform body and brachium conjunctivum to reach the cerebellar cortex with dense terminal labeling in the medial parts of the anterior and posterior lobes.
In general, we found that anterior lobules I1 through V and posterior lobule VIII contained labeled terminals from every major spinal cord level.
The densest terminal labeling in the cerebellar cortex was found following injections that included the lumbar spinal segments.

Results.S: Projections from the rostral cord segments were less dense and some injections failed to label terminals in the most medial areas (e.g., rat3; see below).
Labeled terminals from all injection sites were confined to within 2 mm of the midline (see Table 1).

TTE.S: Figure 1 shows an experiment (rat 7) in which the enzyme injection involved nearly all of laminae 3-7 of Rexed ('54) in the lower thoracic and upper lumbar segments (Tll-L2).
Heavy terminal labeling was present in the medial parts of lobules I through V of the anterior lobe (&lt; 1 mm from the midline) and in lobule VIII of the posterior lobe (cf. Larsell, '52).
Between 1 and 2 mm from the midline, we found labeled terminals only in lobule VIII and no labeling was found more laterally.

Results.S: Morphological features of the orthogradely labeled terminations are illustrated in Figure 2, which shows typical mossy fiber terminals in the granule layer.

TTE.S: Beginning with the most rostral spinal segments (Cl-C4, e.g., rats 1,2; Table 11, injections of enzyme produced a small number of labeled terminals in the medial parts of lobules I, 11, 111, and V of the anterior lobe and in lobules VTI, VIII, and IX of the posterior lobe.
A few labeled terminals were also detected in lobules IV and V between 1 and 2 mm from the midline.
Injections that included lower cervical segments (C5-C6; rat 3) yielded very few labeled terminals in the medial areas which were detectable only in non-counterstained sections.
More labeling was detected laterally (between 1 and 2 mm), but only in lobule VIII of the posterior lobe.
When the injection included the upper thoracic levels (C8-T2; rat 41, there was more labeling in lobules 11, 111, V and VIII which was primarily between 1 and 2 mm from the midline.

Injections confined to the upper thoracic level (Tl-T2; rat 5) produced a similar pattern of labeling between 1 and 2 mm from the midline and also a moderate number of labeled terminals in the medial parts of lobules I1 and 111, and to a lesser degree in lobules IV and V.
Injections that included the middle thoracic segments (T7-T8; rat 6) labeled only a few terminals in lobules I1 and VIII.
As indicated in Table 1, injections involving the lower thoracic and upper lumbar levels (Tll-L3; rats 7,8) produced the heaviest labeling in the cerebellar cortex.
In these experiments, the anterior lobe (lobules I-V) was labeled medially and the posterior lobe (lobule VIII) more laterally (Fig. 1).

When the middle lumbar segments were injected (L2-L5; rats 9,lO) dense labeling was found in the medial parts of both anterior and posterior lobes with the heaviest labeling in lobules 11, 111, and VIII.

Injections covering the lower lumbar and upper sacral segments (rat 11; L5-S2) also produced heavy labeling in the more medial parts of lobules I1 and I11 and a small amount of terminal labeling in lobule VIII.
The few labeled terminals detected with injections of the lower sacral cord (rat 12; SlS3) were also in the medial parts of lobules 11, I11 and VIII.

Results.S: Retrograde double-labeling experiments

TTE.S: Figures 3 and 4 illustrate the results obtained in two of the nine rats in which two retrograde tracers were used.
In one (rat 14), FB was injected in the left anterior lobe and DY in the left posterior lobe (Fig. 3).
In the other (rat 20), WGAapoHRP-Au was injected in the left anterior lobe and FG in the left posterior lobe (Fig. 4).
The two sets of tracers gave comparable results.
The anterior lobe injections labeled neurons in laminae 4-8 and 10 (Rexed, '54) of the cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and sacral spinal cord.
In the upper cervical levels ((2144) labeled cells were generally found in the contralateral central cervical nucleus.
Fewer cells were labeled in the C5-T6 segments and they were mainly within laminae 5 and 7 on the ipsilateral side.
Middle thoracic levels (T5-T9) showed very few labeled cells, in agreement with our finding that orthograde labeling of these segments produced very few labeled terminals in the cerebellum.
In the lower thoracic and lumbar segments, labeled cells were very numerous within laminae 4-7.
The maximal incidence of labeling was in Clarke's columns and in the dorso-lateral parts of lamina 7 with a slight prevalence on the ipsilateral side.
In Clarke's column, the labeled neurons were medium and small elongated cells, while in the doso-lateral part of lamina 7, they were large round neurons with clearly labeled dendrites.
In the sacral cord segments there were only a few labeled cells located in laminae 5 and 7, mainly within the contralateral sacral nucleus of Stilling (Snyder et al., '78).

Results.S: Between 55% and 70% of labeled cells in each section were labeled with tracer from the anterior lobe.
The distribution of cells which were retrogradely labeled by tracer injected into the posterior lobe was very similar to that described above for anterior lobe tracer.
However, as noted, the incidence of labeled cells from the posterior lobe was always lower.

A significant fraction of the double-labeled neurons, i.e., neurons projecting to both anterior and posterior lobes, were found bilaterally in Clarke's column and in the dorsolateral part of lamina 7 in the thoraco-lumbar segments (Figs. 3,4).
The only other double-labeled cells were the few that were found in upper cervical segments.
In the thoracolumbar segments, double-labeling in each section ranged between 13% and 40% of the labeled cells.

In Clarke s columns and the dorsolateral parts of lamina 7 their incidence was between 40 and 50% of the labeled cells with the FB and DY tracers (Fig. 3) and between 50 and 70% with the WGAapoHRP-Au and FG (Fig. 4).
Examples of double-labeled cells in these areas are illustrated in Figure 5 (left: Clarke s column; right: Spinal border).
Table 2 summarizes the results obtained in the 9 rats used for the double-labeling study.

It shows that with the FG and WGAapoHRP-Au tracers we were able to detect about twice as many double-labeled cells as with the other tracers (average of about 19% of the total labeled cells compared with about 10% for the other two tracers).
The FB, DY tracers consistently labeled more cells from the anterior injection site regardless of which of the two tracers was injected there.

The WGAapoHRP-Au, however, seemed to be less effective than the FG in labeling cells in either anterior or posterior lobe (compare rats 18,19 with 20,21, for example), but the differences could be readily accounted for by the smaller volume of tissue infused with the colloidal tracer.
With these small differences taken into account, the results in 9 rats with 4 different tracer combinations were all consistent.
Figure 6 summarizes the data in Table 2.

It shows that more cells are retrogradely labeled in every spinal segment from the anterior lobe than from the posterior lobe and that cells projecting to both the anterior and posterior lobes are confined primarily to the lower thoracic and upper lumbar spinal segments.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

In all mammalian species studied thus far, spinocerebellar fibers are found to project to lobules I-V of the anterior lobe and lobule VIII of the posterior lobe (Snyder et al., '78; Matsushita and Ikeda, '80, '81; Klinkachorn and Culberson, '88).
We observed the same pattern in the rat, where the densest spinocerebellar projections are in lobules 11,111, and VIII.
Moreover, we were unable to demonstrate a difference in the rostral-caudal distribution of projections from different spinal segments in either of the two lobes.

Orthograde tracer injections into different spinal cord levels each produced terminal labeling in nearly the same cortical areas, with no demonstrable segregation in rostralcaudal extent and only a small difference medio-laterally.
For example, projections from T2-T4 to lobule VIII are found in the more lateral parts, between 1 and 2 mm from the midline, whereas those from T12-L2 are found more medially (see Table 1).

In contrast with earlier electrophysiological studies in the cat which suggested a clear rostral-caudal separation between forelimb and hindlimb portions to the cerebellar cortex (Oscarsson, '73), this study is consistent with more recent data (e.g., Leicht and Schmidt, '77) which suggest there may be a substantial convergence of projections from various somatotopic areas.

Such convergence would allow Purkinje cells associated with a particular movement to receive information concerning a large peripheral area, which may play a role in the cerebellum's contribution to motor coordination.
The double-labeling experiments showed that the projections to the anterior and posterior lobes arise primarily from different neurons.
Double-labeled neurons were found almost exclusively within Clarke's column and the dorsolateral part of lamina 7.
Outside of these structures nearly every spinocerebellar neuron exhibited a single label.

Between 40% and 70% of the neurons in the lower thoracic and upper lumbar levels of Clarke's column, which contribute to the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, and of the neurons in the dorso-lateral part of lamina 7 (the spinal border cells; Cooper and Sherrington, '401, which contribute to the ventral spinocerebellar tract, were retrogradely labeled from both anterior and posterior lobes.

The clear and consistent differentiation of a population of cells that were double-labeled implies that the double-labeling observed was not artifactual, for example, not due to the labeling of fibers of passage projecting to the anterior lobe with the posterior label.
If that were the case, we would expect to see a similar percentage of double-labeling in other spinocerebellar neurons as well.
We did find, however, that the WGAapoHRP-Au + FG labeled almost twice as many doubly projecting neurons as did the FB + DY labeling.

This difference may be due to the more intense dye-leaching of the latter tracers (Skirboll et al., '84) and thus the percentage of branching projections may be more accurately indicated by the gold tracers.

It seems reasonable that the greatest percentage of double-labeling represents a lower limit on the actual incidence of branching spinocerebellar neurons since the tracer cannot reach every afferent axon.

Therefore, the results reported here suggest that most, if not all, of the spinocerebellar neurons in these two nuclei project to both anterior and posterior lobe targets, while most or all of the spinocerebellar neurons outside these nuclei and outside the central cervical nucleus project separately to either the anterior lobe or to the posterior lobe.
The possible functional significance of this arrangement is not clear.

However, it is reasonable to suppose that since the majority of the spinocerebellar projections to the anterior or posterior lobe are from separate neurons, these two parts of the cortex may receive qualitatively and/or quantitatively different information and consequently may operate in a different manner.

In support of this view, we recently reported that responses to passive hind foot rotations of Purkinje cells located in the anterior and posterior lobes of the cat cerebellum were qualitatively different (Perciavalle et al., '89).
From a functional point of view it would be interesting to know what role the branching projections play in supplying identical information to these two areas.

It would also be of interest to know if the outputs from these two cortical areas converge on the same cerebellar nuclear cells or if there are also separate neuronal populations at the nuclear level.

Acknowledgements.S: Rosario Giuffrida for suggesting the use of Fluoro Gold together with the WGAapoHRP-Au for the double-labeling studies.
This research was partly supported by grants from the Minister0 della Pubblica Istruzione and the National Institutes of Health, NS 21143.
